Overall Access:

- 72 money transfer institutions

#### DOCUMENT 52: CFA Franc (XAF) - Central African Currency
```
SOURCE_URL: https://ibanfirst.com/currency-reference-centre/xaf
RETRIEVED: 2025-12-03
COUNTRY: CEMAC Regional
CATEGORY: Regional Framework
DOCUMENT_TYPE: Currency Information

CERTAINTY: high
DATE_OF_DOCUMENT: 2024

CONTENT:
Central African CFA Franc (XAF):

Currency of Six States:
1. Cameroon
2. Central African Republic
3. Chad
4. Republic of the Congo
5. Equatorial Guinea
6. Gabon

Issuer:
Bank of Central African States (BEAC), Yaoundé, Cameroon
For members of Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa (CEMAC)

Fixed Exchange Rate:
€1 = 655.957 CFA francs
Aims to provide monetary stability and control inflation within CEMAC region.

Cash Movement Limits:
- Persons traveling into/out of CEMAC member State permitted up to equivalent of XAF 5,000,000 without declaration
- Sums above limit need declaration with customs administration

Large Transfer Notification:
Transfer to non-CEMAC country exceeding XAF 100,000,000 must be notified 30 days in advance to BEAC and Ministry of Finance.

Cryptocurrency Prohibition:
CEMAC guidelines specify can't use cryptocurrencies. All electronic money must be supported by registered institution.
```

#### DOCUMENT 53: CEMAC Foreign Exchange Regulation
```
SOURCE_URL: https://www.beac.int/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/REGULATION_compressed.pdf
RETRIEVED: 2025-12-03
COUNTRY: CEMAC Regional
CATEGORY: Regional Framework
DOCUMENT_TYPE: Regulation
LANGUAGE: English/French
CERTAINTY: high
DATE_OF_DOCUMENT: 2018-12-21

CONTENT:
CEMAC Regulation 02/18/CEMAC/UMAC/CM of December 21, 2018:

Background:
BEAC submitted new set of foreign exchange regulations to Ministerial Committee of Union Monétaire de L'Afrique Centrale (UMAC). Approved December 21, 2018.

Entry into Force: March 1, 2019
Repeals: 2000 Regulation

Export Domiciliation:
Exports of goods exceeding 5 million CFA Francs (around 7,600 EUR) must be domiciled in CEMAC credit institution. Exporter has 150 days from export date to collect and repatriate export income through local bank.

Electronic Payment Requirements (Effective December 1, 2018):
All interbank payment transactions and operations within CEMAC zone with cards or electronic wallets issued by institution operating in sub-region must be cleared and settled in CFA franc.

Applies to:
- Transfers via interoperable payment system or platform
- Operating in CEMAC
- Having BEAC as bank or settlement agent

Regulatory Evolution:
After several years of debate, new Currency Exchange Regulation finally entered into force.
```

#### DOCUMENT 54: GABAC - AML/CFT for CEMAC
```
SOURCE_URL: https://www.fatf-gafi.org/en/countries/global-network/gabac.html
RETRIEVED: 2025-12-03
COUNTRY: CEMAC Regional
CATEGORY: Regional Framework
DOCUMENT_TYPE: Regulatory Framework
LANGUAGE: English
CERTAINTY: high
DATE_OF_DOCUMENT: 2024

CONTENT:
GABAC (Action Group against Money Laundering in Central Africa):

Status:
FATF-Style Regional Body

Role:
Specialized CEMAC institution responsible for promoting norms, instruments and standards to combat:
- Money laundering
- Financing of terrorism
- Financing of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction

AML-CFT Framework:
Assessment focuses on regional Anti-Money Laundering and Combating Financing of Terrorism framework and conformity with international standards.

Reviews:
- Institutional framework
- Laws, regulations, guidelines, other requirements
- Regulatory and other systems to deter ML/TF through financial institutions and designated non-financial businesses (DNFBPs)

Microfinance Context:
In view of importance of cash in zone, savings schemes like tontines (sometimes structured as MFI), and size of informal sector, mobilization of prudential authorities and microfinance institutions required to rigorously tailor AML-CFT obligation to sector.

Reporting Entities in Cameroon:
STR covered entities include: Treasury, central bank, banks, banking intermediaries, microfinance institutions, insurance companies, investment services, money changers, casinos, notaries, real estate agents, money transfer companies, travel agencies, auditors, accountants, high-value goods dealers.

Supervisory Bodies (Cameroon):
- National Financial Investigation Agency (ANIF)
- Central African Banking Commission (COBAC)

Challenge:
Trade-based money laundering rampant and utilizes banking system and microfinance institutions.

Current Status:
Cameroon remains on list of jurisdictions under increased monitoring (Grey List) as of FATF statement October 2025.
```

CEMAC Microfinance Sector NPL Statistics (2024):

Total Non-Performing Loans: 178 billion CFA francs ($295-315 million)
- Increase: 14 billion CFA francs (8.9%) from 2023

Country Breakdown:
- Cameroon: 81% (144 billion CFA francs)
- Congo: 9%
- Gabon: 7%

Licensed MFI Distribution (521 total):
- Cameroon: 384 (74%)
- Chad: 59
- Congo: 46
- Gabon: 18
- Central African Republic: 12
- Equatorial Guinea: 2

BEAC Assessment:
Highlights rising credit risks in microfinance sector, critical for financial inclusion in region.

COBAC NPL Categories:
- Frozen: Overdue over 3 months but recoverable
- Unpaid: Missed due payments
- Doubtful: At risk of partial or no recovery, even with collateral

Banking Sector Context:
CEMAC banking sector exhibits concentration of lending to small number of large borrowers, often connected to political or influential elites. World Bank finds three banks control 50% of assets in CEMAC region.

COBAC July 2024 Action:
Called for temporary halt on transfer of unclaimed assets to Cameroon's Deposits and Consignments Fund (Cdec). Working on "community-wide framework to guide handling of unclaimed assets by credit, microfinance, and payment institutions" to "preserve financial stability within CEMAC."

BEAC Monetary Policy Report (March 2025):

Interest Rates:
After cumulative increase of 175 basis points between November 2021 and March 2023, BEAC maintained policy rate at 5%.

Liquidity Operations:
Weekly liquidity injections discontinued in early 2023.

Economic Growth:
CEMAC economic growth rose from 1.9% in 2023 to 2.6% in 2024.

2024 Liquidity Withdrawal Operations:
BEAC planned three bond issuances targeting community's banks between March 18 and April 1, 2024:
- Total withdrawal: CFA 150 billion from bank vaults
- Part of restrictive monetary policy implemented since 2022 to combat inflation

Governor Abbas Mahamat Tolli Statement (December 12 meeting):
"We will invite the banking community holding surplus funds to submit their interest rate proposals based on the amount of liquidity we aim to extract from the system. Each bank will place their bids, and we will ultimately select a rate to eliminate the surplus liquidity found in these institutions."

Monetary Policy Committee Decisions:
- Tender interest rate: 5.00%
- Marginal lending rate: 6.75%
